    <script src="https://d3js.org/d3.v5.min.js"></script>
    <script>
        const lat = 48.8566;
        const lon = 2.3522;
        const date = '2023-07-25';
        let simulateDay = false;
        let simulateStartTime = null;
        let currentDate = new Date();
        let timer;

        // Fetch prayer times
        fetch(`http://api.aladhan.com/v1/timings/${date}?latitude=${lat}&longitude=${lon}&method=2`)
            .then(response => response.json())
            .then(data => {
                const prayerTimes = data.data.timings;
                displayPrayerTimes(prayerTimes);
                const svg = d3.select('#sky');
                const width = +svg.style('width').slice(0, -2);
                const height = +svg.style('height').slice(0, -2);
                svg.append('circle').attr('id', 'earth').attr('cx', width / 2).attr('cy', height / 2).attr('r', 0.65 * height / 2).attr('fill', 'lightblue').style('z-index', '10');
                svg.append('circle').attr('id', 'sun').attr('r', 20).attr('fill', 'yellow');
                svg.append('text').attr('id', 'sunText').attr('font-size', '12').attr('text-anchor', 'middle');
                svg.append('line').attr('id', 'horizon').attr('x1', 0).attr('y1', 0.8 * height).attr('x2', width).attr('y2', 0.8 * height).attr('stroke', 'black').attr('stroke-width', '1');
                // Draw sun path with different colors for different segments
                drawSunPath(prayerTimes, width, height);
                timer = setInterval(() => {
                    if (simulateDay) {
                        let simulatedDate = new Date(simulateStartTime.getTime() + Date.now() - simulateDay);
                        moveIndicator(simulatedDate, prayerTimes, width, height);
                    } else {
                        currentDate = new Date();
                        moveIndicator(currentDate, prayerTimes, width, height);
                    }
                }, 1000);
            });

        // Event listeners for buttons
        document.getElementById('simulate').addEventListener('click', () => {
            simulateDay = Date.now();
            simulateStartTime = new Date();
        });

        document.getElementById('stopSimulate').addEventListener('click', () => {
            simulateDay = false;
        });

        document.getElementById('endSimulation').addEventListener('click', () => {
            simulateDay = false;
            currentDate = new Date();
            moveIndicator(currentDate, prayerTimes);
        });

        // Display prayer times
        function displayPrayerTimes(times) {
            const timeDiv = d3.select('#prayerTimes');
            timeDiv.html(`Location: Paris, France<br>Prayer Times: ${Object.entries(times).map(([prayer, time]) => `${prayer}: ${time}`).join(', ')}`);
        }

        // Draw the sun path with different colors for different segments
        function drawSunPath(times, width, height) {
            const svg = d3.select('#sky');
            const r = 0.65 * height;
            const cx = width / 2;
            const cy = height / 2;

            const fajrAngle = mapTimeToAngle(times.Fajr, times);
            const sunriseAngle = mapTimeToAngle(times.Sunrise, times);
            const dhuhrAngle = mapTimeToAngle(times.Dhuhr, times);
            const maghribAngle = mapTimeToAngle(times.Maghrib, times);
            const ishaAngle = mapTimeToAngle(times.Isha, times);

            const segments = [
                { start: fajrAngle, end: sunriseAngle, color: 'lightblue' },
                { start: sunriseAngle, end: dhuhrAngle, color: 'yellow' },
                { start: dhuhrAngle, end: maghribAngle, color: 'orange' },
                { start: maghribAngle, end: ishaAngle, color: 'darkblue' },
            ];

            segments.forEach((segment, i) => {
                const id = `sunPathSegment${i}`;
                svg.append('path')
                    .attr('id', id)
                    .attr('fill', 'none')
                    .attr('stroke', segment.color)
                    .attr('stroke-width', 4)
                    .attr('d', describeArc(cx, cy, r, segment.start, segment.end));
                d3.select(`#${id}`).lower();
            });

            svg.append('path')
                .attr('id', 'sunPath')
                .attr('fill', 'none')
                .attr('stroke', 'transparent')
                .attr('stroke-width', 2)
                .attr('stroke-dasharray', '4,4')
                .attr('d', describeArc(cx, cy, r, fajrAngle, ishaAngle));
            d3.select('#sunPath').lower();
        }

        // Convert time string to Date object
        function parseTime(timeStr) {
            const [hours, minutes] = timeStr.split(':').map(Number);
            const date = new Date();
            date.setHours(hours, minutes, 0, 0);
            return date;
        }

        // Convert time string to angle on the circle
        function mapTimeToAngle(time, times) {
            const fajrTime = parseTime(times.Fajr);
            const ishaTime = parseTime(times.Isha);
            const currentTime = parseTime(time);
            const totalDuration = (ishaTime - fajrTime) / 60000;
            const elapsedDuration = (currentTime - fajrTime) / 60000;
            return elapsedDuration / totalDuration * 360;
        }

        // Get SVG arc path string
        function describeArc(x, y, radius, startAngle, endAngle){
            var start = polarToCartesian(x, y, radius, endAngle);
            var end = polarToCartesian(x, y, radius, startAngle);

            var largeArcFlag = endAngle - startAngle <= 180 ? '0' : '1';

            var d = [
                'M', start.x, start.y, 
                'A', radius, radius, 0, largeArcFlag, 0, end.x, end.y
            ].join(' ');

            return d; 
        }

        // Convert polar coordinates to Cartesian
        function polarToCartesian(centerX, centerY, radius, angleInDegrees) {
            var angleInRadians = (angleInDegrees-90) * Math.PI / 180.0;

            return {
                x: centerX + (radius * Math.cos(angleInRadians)),
                y: centerY + (radius * Math.sin(angleInRadians))
            };
        }

        // Move the sun indicator based on the current time
        function moveIndicator(time, times, width, height) {
            const sun = d3.select('#sun');
            const text = d3.select('#sunText');
            const radius = 0.65 * height / 2;
            const angle = mapTimeToAngle(time.toLocaleTimeString('en-US', { hour12: false }), times);
            const x = width / 2 + radius * Math.cos(angle * Math.PI / 180);
            const daylightRatio = (parseTime(times.Maghrib) - parseTime(times.Fajr)) / (24 * 60 * 60 * 1000);
            const y = height / 2 + daylightRatio * radius * Math.sin(angle * Math.PI / 180);
            sun.attr('cx', x).attr('cy', y);
            text.attr('x', x).attr('y', y - 30).text(time.toLocaleTimeString('en-US', { hour12: false }));
        }
    </script>
</body>
</html>

        document.getElementById('simulate').addEventListener('click', () => {
            simulateDay = Date.now();
            simulateStartTime = new Date();
        });

        document.getElementById('stopSimulate').addEventListener('click', () => {
            simulateDay = false;
        });

        document.getElementById('endSimulation').addEventListener('click', () => {
            simulateDay = false;
            currentDate = new Date();
            moveIndicator(currentDate, prayerTimes);
        });

        // Display prayer times
        function displayPrayerTimes(times) {
            const timeDiv = d3.select('#prayerTimes');
            timeDiv.html(`Location: Paris, France<br>Prayer Times: ${Object.entries(times).map(([prayer, time]) => `${prayer}: ${time}`).join(', ')}`);
        }

        // Draw the sun path with different colors for different segments
        function drawSunPath(times, width, height) {
            const svg = d3.select('#sky');
            const r = 0.65 * height;
            const cx = width / 2;
            const cy = height / 2;

            const fajrAngle = mapTimeToAngle(times.Fajr, times);
            const sunriseAngle = mapTimeToAngle(times.Sunrise, times);
            const dhuhrAngle = mapTimeToAngle(times.Dhuhr, times);
            const maghribAngle = mapTimeToAngle(times.Maghrib, times);
            const ishaAngle = mapTimeToAngle(times.Isha, times);

            const segments = [
                { start: fajrAngle, end: sunriseAngle, color: 'lightblue' },
                { start: sunriseAngle, end: dhuhrAngle, color: 'yellow' },
                { start: dhuhrAngle, end: maghribAngle, color: 'orange' },
                { start: maghribAngle, end: ishaAngle, color: 'darkblue' },
            ];

            segments.forEach((segment, i) => {
                const id = `sunPathSegment${i}`;
                svg.append('path')
                    .attr('id', id)
                    .attr('fill', 'none')
                    .attr('stroke', segment.color)
                    .attr('stroke-width', 4)
                    .attr('d', describeArc(cx, cy, r, segment.start, segment.end));
                d3.select(`#${id}`).lower();
            });

            svg.append('path')
                .attr('id', 'sunPath')
                .attr('fill', 'none')
                .attr('stroke', 'transparent')
                .attr('stroke-width', 2)
                .attr('stroke-dasharray', '4,4')
                .attr('d', describeArc(cx, cy, r, fajrAngle, ishaAngle));
            d3.select('#sunPath').lower();
        }

        // Convert time string to Date object
        function parseTime(timeStr) {
            const [hours, minutes] = timeStr.split(':').map(Number);
            const date = new Date();
            date.setHours(hours, minutes, 0, 0);
            return date;
        }

        // Convert time string to angle on the circle
        function mapTimeToAngle(time, times) {
            const fajrTime = parseTime(times.Fajr);
            const ishaTime = parseTime(times.Isha);
            const currentTime = parseTime(time);
            const totalDuration = (ishaTime - fajrTime) / 60000;
            const elapsedDuration = (currentTime - fajrTime) / 60000;
            return elapsedDuration / totalDuration * 360;
        }

        // Get SVG arc path string
        function describeArc(x, y, radius, startAngle, endAngle){
            var start = polarToCartesian(x, y, radius, endAngle);
            var end = polarToCartesian(x, y, radius, startAngle);

            var largeArcFlag = endAngle - startAngle <= 180 ? '0' : '1';

            var d = [
                'M', start.x, start.y, 
                'A', radius, radius, 0, largeArcFlag, 0, end.x, end.y
            ].join(' ');

            return d; 
        }

        // Convert polar coordinates to Cartesian
        function polarToCartesian(centerX, centerY, radius, angleInDegrees) {
            var angleInRadians = (angleInDegrees-90) * Math.PI / 180.0;

            return {
                x: centerX + (radius * Math.cos(angleInRadians)),
                y: centerY + (radius * Math.sin(angleInRadians))
            };
        }

        // Move the sun indicator based on the current time
        function moveIndicator(time, times, width, height) {
            const sun = d3.select('#sun');
            const text = d3.select('#sunText');
            const radius = 0.65 * height / 2;
            const angle = mapTimeToAngle(time.toLocaleTimeString('en-US', { hour12: false }), times);
            const x = width / 2 + radius * Math.cos(angle * Math.PI / 180);
            const daylightRatio = (parseTime(times.Maghrib) - parseTime(times.Fajr)) / (24 * 60 * 60 * 1000);
            const y = height / 2 + daylightRatio * radius * Math.sin(angle * Math.PI / 180);
            sun.attr('cx', x).attr('cy', y);
            text.attr('x', x).attr('y', y - 30).text(time.toLocaleTimeString('en-US', { hour12: false }));
        }
    </script>

> remember these points: Compute the number of daylight hours: The existing code does not compute the number of daylight hours. It assumes that daylight is from Fajr to Maghrib, which is not necessarily the case throughout the year due to seasonal changes.

Adjust the horizon line: In the existing code, the horizon line is fixed. According to your pseudocode, we need to adjust the horizon line based on the number of daylight hours. The higher the number of daylight hours, the lower the horizon line should be and vice versa.

Move the sun considering Fajr as the starting point: The existing code starts the sun at the rightmost point of the sun path, which does not correspond to the Fajr prayer time. The pseudocode takes into account the Fajr prayer time as the starting point of the sun.

    <script>
        const width = 500;
        const height = 500;
        const radius = 240;
        const lat = 51.5074; // London
        const lon = -0.1278; // London
        const date = new Date().toISOString().split('T')[0]; // Today's date

            .attr('x1', 0)
            .attr('y1', height / 2)
            .attr('x2', width)
            .attr('y2', height / 2);

            .then(response => response.json())
            .then(data => {
                const prayerTimes = data.data.timings;
                const dayLengthSeconds = (parseTime(prayerTimes.Maghrib) - parseTime(prayerTimes.Fajr)) / 1000;
                const horizonLineHeight = mapDayLengthToHorizonHeight(dayLengthSeconds);
                horizon.attr('y1', horizonLineHeight).attr('y2', horizonLineHeight);
                drawSunPath(prayerTimes, width, height);
                const distancePerSecond = 2 * Math.PI * radius / 86400;

                timer = setInterval(() => {
                    if (simulateDay) {
                        let simulatedSeconds = Math.floor((Date.now() - simulateDay) / 1000);
                        let simulatedDate = new Date(simulateStartTime.getTime() + simulatedSeconds * 1000);
                        moveIndicator(simulatedDate, prayerTimes, width, height, distancePerSecond, dayLengthSeconds);
                    } else {
                        currentDate = new Date();
                        moveIndicator(currentDate, prayerTimes, width, height, distancePerSecond, dayLengthSeconds);
                    }
                }, 1000);
            });

        d3.select('#today').on('click', () => {
            clearInterval(timer);
            simulateDay = null;
            currentDate = new Date();
        });

        d3.select('#simulateDay').on('click', () => {
            clearInterval(timer);
            simulateDay = Date.now();
            simulateStartTime = new Date();
            simulateStartTime.setHours(0, 0, 0, 0);
        });

        function mapDayLengthToHorizonHeight(dayLengthSeconds) {
            const maxDayLength = 16 * 3600; // Maximum possible day length is approximated to be 16 hours
            const horizonHeight = height / 2 + ((dayLengthSeconds - maxDayLength / 2) / maxDayLength) * height / 2;
            return Math.max(horizonHeight, 0);
        }

        function drawSunPath(times, width, height) {
            const svg = d3.select('#sky');
            svg.selectAll('path').remove();

            const segments = [
                { start: times.Isha, end: times.Fajr, color: 'black' },

                { start: times.Maghrib, end: times.Isha, color: 'purple' },
            ];

            const line = d3.line()
                .x(d => d.x)
                .y(d => d.y);

            segments.forEach(segment => {
                const startAngle = mapTimeToAngle(segment.start, times);
                const endAngle = mapTimeToAngle(segment.end, times);
                const points = d3.range(startAngle, endAngle, 1).map(angle => {
                    const radians = angle * Math.PI / 180;
                    return {
                        x: width / 2 + radius * Math.cos(radians),
                        y: height / 2 - radius * Math.sin(radians),
                    };
                });
                svg.append('path')
                    .attr('d', line(points))
                    .attr('stroke', segment.color)
                    .attr('stroke-width', 2)
                    .attr('fill', 'none');
            });

            const timePoints = ['Isha', 'Fajr', 'Sunrise', 'Dhuhr', 'Asr', 'Maghrib'];
            timePoints.forEach(time => {
                const angle = mapTimeToAngle(times[time], times);
                const radians = angle * Math.PI / 180;
                const x = width / 2 + radius * Math.cos(radians);
                const y = height / 2 - radius * Math.sin(radians);
                svg.append('text')
                    .attr('class', 'timeText')
                    .attr('x', x)
                    .attr('y', y)
                    .text(time + ' ' + times[time]);
            });
        }

        function mapTimeToAngle(time, times) {
            const start = parseTime(times.Fajr);
            const end = parseTime(times.Isha);
            const current = parseTime(time);
            const angle = (current - start) / (end - start) * 360;
            return angle;
        }

        function parseTime(time) {
            const [hours, minutes] = time.split(':');
            const date = new Date();
            date.setHours(+hours);
            date.setMinutes(+minutes);
            return date;
        }

        function moveIndicator(time, times, width, height, distancePerSecond, dayLengthSeconds) {
            const angle = mapTimeToAngle(time.toLocaleTimeString('en-US', { hour12: false }), times);
            const secondsIntoDay = (time - parseTime(times.Fajr)) / 1000;
            const distanceTravelled = Math.min(secondsIntoDay, dayLengthSeconds) * distancePerSecond;
            const x = width / 2 + radius * Math.cos(distanceTravelled / radius);
            const y = height / 2 - radius * Math.sin(distanceTravelled / radius);
            sun.attr('cx', x).attr('cy', y);
            sunText.attr('x', x).attr('y', y - 30).text(time.toLocaleTimeString('en-US', { hour12: false }) + ' ' + getCurrentPrayerTime(time, times));
        }

        function getCurrentPrayerTime(currentTime, times) {
            const prayerTimes = ['Isha', 'Fajr', 'Sunrise', 'Dhuhr', 'Asr', 'Maghrib'];
            for (let i = 0; i < prayerTimes.length; i++) {
                if (currentTime < parseTime(times[prayerTimes[i]])) {
                    return prayerTimes[i - 1];
                }
            }
            return 'Isha';
        }
    </script>

}

function drawSunPath(times) {

        { start: times.Fajr, end: times.Sunrise, color: 'pink' },
        { start: times.Sunrise, end: times.Dhuhr, color: 'lightblue' },
        { start: times.Dhuhr, end: times.Asr, color: 'yellow' },
        { start: times.Asr, end: times.Maghrib, color: 'orange' },
        { start: times.Maghrib, end: times.Isha, color: 'purple' },
        { start: times.Isha, end: addTime(times.Fajr, 24), color: 'black' },
    ];

    const line = d3.line().x(d => d.x).y(d => d.y);

    segments.forEach(segment => {
        const startAngle = mapTimeToAngle(segment.start, times);
        const endAngle = mapTimeToAngle(segment.end, times);
        const points = d3.range(endAngle, startAngle, 0.1).map(angle => {
            const radians = angle * Math.PI / 180;
            return { x: radius * Math.cos(radians), y: -radius * Math.sin(radians) };
        });
        svg.append('path').attr('d', line(points)).attr('stroke', segment.color).attr('stroke-width', 2).attr('fill', 'none');
    });

    const timePoints = ['Fajr', 'Sunrise', 'Dhuhr', 'Asr', 'Maghrib', 'Isha'];
    timePoints.forEach(time => {

        const x = radius * Math.cos(radians);
        const y = -radius * Math.sin(radians);
        const textAnchor = ["Asr", "Maghrib", "Isha"].includes(time) ? "start" : "end";
        svg.append('text').attr('class', 'timeText').attr('x', x).attr('y', y).attr('text-anchor', textAnchor).text(time + ' ' + times[time]);
    });

}

// Parse a time string into a Date object
function parseTime(time) {
    const [hours, minutes] = time.split(':');
    const date = new Date();
    date.setHours(+hours);
    date.setMinutes(+minutes);
    return date;
}

// Add hours to a time string
function addTime(time, hoursToAdd) {
    const [hours, minutes] = time.split(':').map(Number);
    const totalHours = hours + hoursToAdd;
    const newHours = totalHours % 24;
    return `${newHours.toString().padStart(2, '0')}:${minutes.toString().padStart(2, '0')}`;
}

    return fetch(`http://api.aladhan.com/v1/timings/${date.getDate()}-${date.getMonth()+1}-${date.getFullYear()}?latitude=${lat}&longitude=${lon}&method=2`)
        .then(res => res.json())
        .then(data => data.data.timings);
}

function getPrayerDayBoundaries(times) {
    const start = parseTime(times.Fajr);
    const end = parseTime(times.Isha);
    return { start, end };

function mapTimeToRadians(time, times) {
    const angle = mapTimeToAngle(time, times);
    // convert the angle from degrees to radians
    const radians = (angle - 90) * Math.PI / 180;
    return radians;
}

function getSunPosition(radians) {
    const x = radius * Math.cos(radians);
    const y = radius * Math.sin(radians);
    return { x, y };
}

// Fetch prayer times
function fetchPrayerTimes() {
    const today = new Date();
    const tomorrow = new Date(today);
    tomorrow.setDate(tomorrow.getDate() + 1);

    const promises = [
        fetchPrayerTimesForDay(today),
        fetchPrayerTimesForDay(tomorrow)
    ];

    Promise.all(promises)
        .then(([todayTimes, tomorrowTimes]) => {
            const prayerTimes = {
                ...todayTimes,
                Fajr_tomorrow: tomorrowTimes.Fajr
            }

            const {start, end} = getPrayerDayBoundaries(prayerTimes);
            const dayLengthSeconds = (end - start) / 1000;
            const distancePerSecond = 2 * Math.PI * radius / dayLengthSeconds;

            timer = setInterval(() => {
                const currentTime = new Date();
                moveIndicator(currentTime, prayerTimes, distancePerSecond, dayLengthSeconds);
            }, 1000);
            drawSunPath(prayerTimes);
        });
}

A General of the Venezuelan Air Force has just sworn allegiance to Guaido. Not surprising information&c;a& but it revolves around this expression "to make allegiance". His meaning is very simple and very clear: General Yanez Rodriguez no longer recognizes the authority of Maduro and sided with Guaido. He changes his leader! He was under the authority of the President of the Republic. He places himself deliberately&c;a& that is to say on purpose&c;a& under that of the one who disputes him the power. He affirms his loyalty to the man who presents himself as the new head of state. The word&c;a& in French&c;a& comes from the Middle Ages and feudal practices&c;a& that is to say&c;a& which regulates the relations between the different lords. It is a hierarchy&c;a& that is to say an organization of powers&c;a& quite precise: each lord is under the authority of another&c;a& and that goes back to the king&c;a& who is only under the authority of God. He who has authority is the suzerain. He who obeys him is the vassal. And each noble is suzerain of him to whom he commands&c;a& and vassal of him to whom he obeys. And to make allegiance is to recognize someone&c;a& officially and solemnly&c;a& as his overlord. The expression can be used&c;a& as is the case here&c;a& if one changes sides: one shows it by designating the one one accepts as his superior. But we often hear the formula if someone has decided to have no leader at all&c;a& to be on his own&c;a& to admit no one's authority. And then things do not work as expected. The rebel does not escape&c;a& and he decides to return to the rank and again to obey a tutelage: he pledges allegiance to the one who represents this authority. -

$01307125$$$ 2018-03-15 07:08:39 $01307125$$$

Makeup.

A potential enhancer&c;a& a filter with "imperfections"&c;a& a subterfuge of seduction&c;a& a creative and theatrical adornment&c;a& a social cover ...

For me&c;a& makeup has long been a set of unknown products reserved for "women". A term that seemed to me then excluding for the girl little feminine and flirt that I was.

First&c;a& my personal quest for truth forced me to exclude the wearing of a mask. But how to determine what is a personal choice of what is social convention? The border was thin&c;a& and the reasons for my refusal of makeup more numerous.

The societal consensus around a feminine ideal is&c;a& of course&c;a& binding for women in the first place&c;a& but also for men&c;a& who unconsciously integrate this model of beauty - which I do not wish to perpetuate.

In a second time&c;a& I questioned the usefulness of make-up in a context of personal confidence. If such a small detail can contribute to the improvement of personal well-being&c;a& is not it worth it to pay attention to it?

After a few months of use&c;a& I developed a psychological dependence on this seemingly precarious apparatus. This thin layer of pigments alone had inhibited my ability to accept some of my appearance - my skin&c;a& my face! - and developed in parallel an addiction to - not a feeling of well-being - but the absence of malaise.

Because wearing this makeup that hides a few buttons and highlights my blue eyes&c;a& it was not a way to accentuate my confidence and my strengths&c;a& it was now a necessity to make them exist.

Conscious of this discomfort&c;a& I proceeded by step to detox me gently. My cure was to remove one ingredient at a time&c;a& then choose a "no" day&c;a& until you reach a majority of "no" days a week.

Of course the days of greatest importance were those where I exposed myself to the greatest number of social interactions&c;a& and those days represented huge steps to be taken for my personal self-esteem.

Because if my confidence in me is far from being reduced to my mere appearance&c;a& the environment in which I evolve does not deprive myself of judging me on this criterion "at first sight".

Today&c;a& -

The word&c;a& in French&c;a& comes from the Middle Ages and feudal practices&c;a& that is to say&c;a& which regulates the relations between the different lords. And to make allegiance is to recognize someone&c;a& officially and solemnly&c;a& as his overlord. The expression can be used&c;a& as is the case here&c;a& if one changes sides: one shows it by designating the one one accepts as his superior. Makeup.

A potential enhancer&c;a& a filter with "imperfections"&c;a& a subterfuge of seduction&c;a& a creative and theatrical adornment&c;a& a social cover ...

For me&c;a& makeup has long been a set of unknown products reserved for "women". A term that seemed to me then excluding for the girl little feminine and flirt that I was.

First&c;a& my personal quest for truth forced me to exclude the wearing of a mask. But how to determine what is a personal choice of what is social convention? The border was thin&c;a& and the reasons for my refusal of makeup more numerous.

The societal consensus around a feminine ideal is&c;a& of course&c;a& binding for women in the first place&c;a& but also for men&c;a& who unconsciously integrate this model of beauty - which I do not wish to perpetuate.

In a second time&c;a& I questioned the usefulness of make-up in a context of personal confidence. If such a small detail can contribute to the improvement of personal well-being&c;a& is not it worth it to pay attention to it?

After a few months of use&c;a& I developed a psychological dependence on this seemingly precarious apparatus. This thin layer of pigments alone had inhibited my ability to accept some of my appearance - my skin&c;a& my face! - and developed in parallel an addiction to - not a feeling of well-being - but the absence of malaise.

Because wearing this makeup that hides a few buttons and highlights my blue eyes&c;a& it was not a way to accentuate my confidence and my strengths&c;a& it was now a necessity to make them exist.

Conscious of this discomfort&c;a& I proceeded by step to detox me gently. My cure was to remove one ingredient at a time&c;a& then choose a "no" day&c;a& until you reach a majority of "no" days a week.

Of course the days of greatest importance were those where I exposed myself to the greatest number of social interactions&c;a& and those days represented huge steps to be taken for my personal self-esteem.

Because if my confidence in me is far from being reduced to my mere appearance&c;a& the environment in which I evolve does not deprive myself of judging me on this criterion "at first sight".

Today&c;a& -

Make a saturated sugar solution 2019-11-19 12:38:48 Make a saturated sugar solution

Cover 1kg of sand with water and place in a crockpot at 90-95oC for 6 hours continually stirring

https://www.amazon.fr/dp/B07D6K47HT?aaxitk=rnL.nb9DEpIHo-MmgScAfQ&pd\_rd\_i=B07D6K47HT&pf\_rd\_p=b9d09903-589f-4d25-a664-7518f8307b01&hsa\_cr\_id=6065168840802&sb-ci-n=productDescription&sb-ci-v=Crock%20Pot%20CSC051X-01%20Multi-Cuiseur%20Express%2C%20Mijoteuse%2C%20Cuiseur%20Vapeur%20et%20Saut%C3%A9%20Programmables%2012%20en%201-5%201000%20W%206%20L%20Argent&sb-ci-a=B07D6K47HT

Take it out and heat it to 200oC in a conventional oven or toaster oven

Slowly heat it up and stir it start at 90&c;a& take it out and stir it

100o take it out stir it

120 take it out stir it

140 take it out stir it

150o we start to approach the caramelization point of sugar so we need to take it out and stir more frequently

155 160 165 170 175 180 185 190 195 200

And so on till you get to 200oC

At 200o leave it for an hour

Take it into a stainless steel bowl and cover with a piece of paper and on top of the paper add activated carbon to create a non reactive atmosphere

Final stage is to add 96-98% sulfuric acid soak it for 30 mins

Pour out extra acid and dry it at

120o for about an hour to make ultrasand

TADA!

Poem: 2019-11-19 12:20:23 Poem:

Love is a creative act - an intense thing to being together two universes

Entire meaning making machines

And asking them to sing together asking about the possibility that we are not lonely

Not Lone in our manifestingbof meaning from void

Beyond all the superficial

Everyone has a mind - a consciousness

And our actions are both and

The sudden springing of action off the top of the water when you rub your finger on its rim

That feeling we have of maybe him

Her

Maybe together

I am more than complete in my aloneness

I am completion

Yet perhaps we

Is better than me

In my greatness I see that I am everything

In my humility I see that everything is everything

And in the tension of emerging possibility

Of collapsing waveforms influenced by people's mastery of mind

That maybe loving another

And bringing them close

To be in awe of the show we are creating

Will allow softness to become strength

And

Perhaps it's more than true

That love concurs all

Starts with a portal into another self

Another uni verse

Another word smith

Forging meaning from concepts wrought from the thoughts before time

In a rare space&c;a& not due to any specialness of being - simply a consequence of time. Being alive is special

Being human is absurdly unlikely

Being a human with the ability to consider ones thoughts - a fleeting chance to be born as such

Being brave enough to peruse and accept what you think - timeless

I am not a messenger because the mediums we live in transmit all we need to know - I am an agent who's learning the ropes of mastery of my own mind

Certainly! To better understand your current situation and help you pick the right activity from the list, please answer the following questions:

1Q.What are your top three personal and professional learning goals at this stage in your career?

1A. I would like to become more of an expert in something rather than a generalist. I feel like I'm all over the place and I have a hard time being seen as a professional both for my own self image and externally. I need to make more money as. my wife is pregnant and we'll need to manage larger expenses. Professional learning, I would like to learn transferrable skills that make me competitive in the job market while also being a rockstar at my own organization, Bloom.

2Q. How would you describe your current strengths and areas for improvement?

2A. I'm nerdy, great at research, I get lost on questions when they capture me like how should I use ChatGPT for work. And I ignore lots of important things that don't, which is a weakness.

3Q. Which aspects of Bloom.pm's growth and development are you most directly involved in or responsible for?

3A. I am responsible at Bloom for our curriculum and training. I'm a facilitator of a new program. I am also attempting to identify new program styles that we can run faster and for different audiences. We run training programs that use assessments and libraries of interventions to help people grow personally and professionally. If you have ideas about how to use chat GPT in that instance, give me a prompt showing that.

4Q. What are the main challenges or obstacles you and Bloom.pm are currently facing?

4A. obstacles are that we need more clients, we are a nonprofit accelerator and our budgets are capped and we have a small amount of overhead for creativity, well-being activities at work, etc. We want corporate clients, or to sell the software we're making

5Q. How do you see your role evolving within Bloom.pm in the near future?

5A. I see myself stabilizing the organization and being focused on research, creative work, values alignment, working on new financial models to support social enterprises, new program design to bring those financial models to life, etc.

6Q. Are there any specific skills or knowledge areas you'd like to develop further to enhance your contributions to Bloom.pm?

6A. I want to learn more about economics and human values and international policy. I wonder if we can have a beautiful future of people living their values at work and also have the sort of scalable growth we have. Lots of question about meaning and money and life and death.

7Q. Based on your assessment results and the information provided so far, which activities from the list resonate the most with you and why?

7A. I'm interested in practical things I can do that involve others, reading a book or doing an activity alone won't captivate me. I should do something where we can work together - perhaps online on a zoom call that will help me share my research and also help the team connect and overcome my problem of procrastination and continual research by allowing myself to work with people who have a different mindset, the fishing sort of mindset that turns ideas into done. That's the problem I'm facing, how to stop innovating and get things to done, especially get things to done that we can sell. I'm also scared to call people - that fear leads to procrastination.

8Q. Do you have any preferences for the type of learning activity, such as reading, workshops, or online courses?

8A. I prefer online courses and activities with great facilitation around areas I'm interested in. I also have a problem where I love reading yet I don't take good enough notes and even if I do I don't know how to turn notes into productive action for Bloom.

\## Title

\## Welcome!

Let's work on Human Relations (HR) strategy with HR expert Joseph Hajj.

In this activity, you will learn more about the fundamental pillars of HR

needed for a healthy, happy work environment. üòÑ

Think about these questions as you watch the video and review the External

Resources:

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 1: The Challenges Ahead

\## Welcome!

üå± In this activity, Giordano Dichter introduces you to the foundation of the

work to be done and the change needed to build your accelerator's

sustainability plan.

Some of the topics discussed in this activity include:

üåª The accelerator's business model challenges and limitations

üåª The need for diversification

üåª The target user and the strong suit

üåª The Ecosystem mapping

While you watch the video, think about the following questions:

ü§î Who are your target users? Who are the (potential) entrepreneurs you are

trying to help?

ü§î What is your strong suit with respect to your peers? What is your

differentiation factor (the one thing you are good at)?

ü§î What is your ecosystem looking like, and who could be interested in funding

your operations?

\## Let's get started!

\[üé¨ Watch the video here\](https://vimeo.com/737809645)

\[document\](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Y9fue4PsXvplhJBpSoHUlzDDdiu6fW96/view?usp=sharing)

that identifies ways to catalyze finance for climate technology incubators and

accelerators in developing countries.

\## Apply your knowledge!

üë§ **Step 1:** Define your target users using the \[User Canvas

Then think about what makes you unique regarding the support you provide to

the users defined.

context where you operate, and fill them out in the first tab of the ecosystem

worksheet according to their priorities. Use the \[Ecosystem

to help you achieve this task.

üìã **Step 3:** Draw up a quick value proposition for each of the #1 ranking

actors and fill them out in the second tab of the ecosystem worksheet.

\## Title

\## Welcome!

Let's get started!

Organizational culture is a key factor of company sustainability. In today's

challenging and turbulent times, it is necessary to shift to a values-driven

culture. Rethinking how weave our collective values into our strategy and

business objectives will increase motivation, improve performance, and drive

results ‚úÖ

As you watch the video, think about the following questions:

üåª Why are values important in a company?

üåª What are some examples of limiting, fear-driven values?

üåª What are the core values of your company? Are they clear and well-defined?

culture.

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 2: Values Based Recruitment & Cultural Fit

\## Welcome!

What tools can you use to build a strong team culture?

Values based recruitment (VBR) is an approach to help attract and recruit

prospective employees whose personal values and behaviors align with those of

your organization. The best way to deliver VBR is through a Cultural Fit

Assessment.

As you watch the video, think about these questions:

üåª What are your team's core values that will attract good candidates?

üåª What are some sample interview questions that target your core values?

‚úçÔ∏è Take notes! It will help you complete the rest of the action.

\## Let's get started!

\[üé¨ Watch the video here\](https://vimeo.com/546366033)

\## Explore some more...

\* \[This article\](https://www.aaronwallis.co.uk/candidates/advice/sales-interview-advice/how-to-wow-at-value-based-interview/) gives a candidate's perspective on VBR.

\* This is an \[in-depth article\](https://www.aihr.com/blog/cultural-fit-assessment/) about Cultural Fit Assessments.

\* \[This article\](https://www.jobtestprep.com/culture-fit-test-prep#:~:text=Examples%20of%20Culture,culture%20interview%20questions%3A) lists some sample Cultural Fit interview questions.

\## Apply your knowledge!

It's time to create a Cultural Fit Assessment for your company ü•≥ Many samples

are available online, however, it is key that this document reflect your own

unique culture.

1\\. Now that your values are clear, write 3 behaviors that support each value

(must be an action sentence). For example:

Value: Social Awareness

Behavior 1: Analyze the internal and external social environment before taking

action.

2\\. Draft a culture fit questionnaire encompassing not more than 10 questions

(you can add more questions later).

Make sure you cover the 2 parts we discussed in the video:

\* Questions to bring personal values and behaviors to the surface.

\* Questions to benchmark and assess alignment with the core values of the organization.

üôå Great work! Save this document with your team's HR library. When the time

comes to recruit new team members, incorporate it into your interview process.

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 3: Highly Performing Team Dynamics & Development

\## Welcome!

Welcome to the final üéì Training Activity with Christine Francis! This activity

will help you understand the different stages of team culture and the role of

a strong team culture in achieving your goals üèÜ

üë´ A highly performing team is a group of people who work together harmoniously

to achieve an outcome much bigger than the number of people on the team if

they were to work individually. Direction is key to clarity, alignment is what

makes the team coherent, and commitment is what ensures success. The diversity

of the team members is important when it comes to thinking, skills sets,

expertise, and points of view. Diversity fuels innovation, but values and

cultural fit are key components of a successful enterprise.

As you watch the video, consider these questions:

üåª What are the four stages of the Tuckman Team Development Model?

üåª What are the communication and strength profiles of your team?

üåª What will it look like when your team starts "performing?"

\## Let's get started!

\[üé¨ Watch the video here\](https://vimeo.com/546439139)

\## Explore some more...

\* \[discprofile.com\](https://www.discprofile.com/) offers a workplace personality profiling service.

\## Apply your knowledge!

The 4 key components of highly effective teams when it comes to performance

and results are:

1\. Shared values and clear vision of KPI‚Äôs - **The What**!

2\. Who are our team members? What are their roles? How do their roles link to KPIs? - **The Who!**

3\. What is the plan to execute or achieve your vision? - **The How!**

4\. What is the timeline, the phases, etc.? - **The When**!

Briefly reflect on each of these points, then continue onto the Worksheet

linked below.

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 2: Collecting and Protecting Your Company Data

\## Welcome!

This activity covers processes related to gathering data for your accelerator

programs.

The EU has the most comprehensive and up-to-date regulations for data

compliance, so Anna's recommendations are based on these standards. However,

they can be adapted to any legal context with the help of a data compliance

expert. The topics include:

üåª Why data matters to accelerator programs.

üåª How to collect the right data for our needs.

üåª Where and how to collect it and how to process it, including the

responsibilities of the person on your team who looks after your data

collection and protection process.

üåª Further information about processing data, covering how to work with it in a

responsible and secure way.

üìù There's lots of valuable information here, so feel free to pause, take

notes, rewatch, or any other strategies that help you process.

\## Let's get started!

\[üé¨ Watch the video here\](https://vimeo.com/737823777)

\## Explore some more...

The actions stated in the EU's \[GDPR Checklist\](https://gdpr.eu/checklist/)

are the main things that a business needs to do in order to stay compliant.

Four important processes you need to have are:

\* The EU's \[Data Processing Agreement template\](https://gdpr.eu/data-processing-agreement/)

\* The EU‚Äôs \[template Privacy Policy\](https://gdpr.eu/privacy-notice/) for a website

\* Here is the EU‚Äôs \[advice on a Cookie Policy for a website\](https://gdpr.eu/cookies/), but they do not have a template. There are lots of companies today providing a service of being the pop-up on your website to deal with cookies permissions.

\* Here is a \[template of a GDPR register\](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1U71Qwtvt3gqXJUl3XvRkm9Wy28cSiRxo5f9V2farldo/edit?usp=sharing), which should be updated regularly in order to remain compliant with GDPR law. This template is only a guideline and should be checked with a local legal advisor before being implemented.

With these four things - a Data Protection Agreement, a Privacy Policy, a

Cookie Policy, and a GDPR Register - you are making good progress toward being

GDPR compliant. In all of your agreements, you should make sure that you add a

GDPR clause, but for this, you will need to seek local legal advice. Just ask

a local expert or data lawyer for the appropriate paragraphs to add.

\## Apply your knowledge!

Using \[this

spreadsheet\](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TCEMeP2iYcVpM9\_u221xlURHdWIudueY6dm9UsewtLY/edit?usp=sharing),

make a list of what kind of digital data you currently collect and what other

data you want to collect and why.

Share this list with other accelerators to see what data they think is

important to collect and why. Discuss together the challenges of collecting

data and how to overcome these challenges.

Finally, complete this \[example Risk & Asset

Register\](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1-fqQhL2Z8UGahiiQS\_gUUFfkkLhFCiCrYw71Z-Huj8E/edit?usp=sharing)

for your accelerator.

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 1: Story Pitching

\## Welcome!

People remember stories, and we are more attracted to an idea when it is

presented using a smooth flow of ideas üåä Follow Andre through this three-part

session about how to pitch using storytelling techniques.

While you watch these videos, consider these questions:

üåª What are the 3 key selling points of your startup?

üåª What is the ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù (or transformation/impact) that you want your audience

to take away from your pitch?

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 1: Finding Your Market

\## Welcome!

Ready to begin? üòÑ This first training activity with Anthony Haddad will guide

you through the process of analyzing different potential markets. In this

training activity, you will learn how to 1) identify the highest potential

market for you, 2) conduct a thorough market analysis, and 3) develop a clear

strategy for choosing a target market.

You might feel like your market has already been chosen for you, but think

outside the box üí° What are the benefits of operating in your home city vs.

another city? Could opportunities exist in other markets that are more

difficult to access? Don't be afraid to dream big üí≠

While you watch Anthony present, reflect on these questions:

1\. üåªWhat is your current target market? Why did you choose it?

2\. üåªWhat market research have you already done?

3\. üåªWhat market research methodology will be most useful to you? (Hint: think from an investor's perspective).

\## Welcome!

We all have two dogs inside of us: one dog is positive, happy, optimistic, and

hopeful; the other dog is negative, mad, sad, pessimistic, and fearful. These

two dogs often fight inside us. The one who wins the fight is the one you feed

better.

positivity

I stopped believing, too, and lost heart‚Ä¶there were all the other things to

trivial and commonplace. My work lost all meaning. On stage I didn‚Äôt know what

seagull. No, that‚Äôs not me‚Ä¶you remember how you once shot that seagull? A man

happened to come along and see her, and having nothing much to do, destroyed

about acting‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not like that anymore. I‚Äôve become a real actress. I love

about acting‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not like that anymore. I‚Äôve become a real actress. I love

beautiful. While I‚Äôve been back here I‚Äôve spent a lot of time walking and

thinking ‚Äì and every day I‚Äôve felt my spirit getting stronger. What I‚Äôve

in myself now and that‚Äôs helped the pain, and when I think to myself, "You‚Äôre

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 1: The Challenges Ahead

\## Welcome!

üå± In this activity, Giordano Dichter introduces you to the foundation of the

work to be done and the change needed to build your accelerator's

sustainability plan.

Some of the topics discussed in this activity include:

üåª The accelerator's business model challenges and limitations

üåª The need for diversification

üåª The target user and the strong suit

üåª The Ecosystem mapping

While you watch the video, think about the following questions:

ü§î Who are your target users? Who are the (potential) entrepreneurs you are

trying to help?

ü§î What is your strong suit with respect to your peers? What is your

differentiation factor (the one thing you are good at)?

ü§î What is your ecosystem looking like, and who could be interested in funding

your operations?

\## Let's get started!

\[üé¨ Watch the video here\](https://vimeo.com/737809645)

\## Explore some more...

Check this

\[document\](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Y9fue4PsXvplhJBpSoHUlzDDdiu6fW96/view?usp=sharing)

that identifies ways to catalyze finance for climate technology incubators and

accelerators in developing countries.

\## Apply your knowledge!

üë§ **Step 1:** Define your target users using the \[User Canvas

worksheet\](https://docs.google.com/document/d/19i89AxLet4v7X5aGaqtJwd3eA05gQD1nKOnRkPqX\_IE/edit?usp=sharing).

Then think about what makes you unique regarding the support you provide to

the users defined.

üåê **Step 2:** Map the ecosystem players interested in financing you in the

context where you operate, and fill them out in the first tab of the ecosystem

worksheet according to their priorities. Use the \[Ecosystem

Worksheet\](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1srz-6TFa8TEtq9bhHGUsSpC\_Rmttktt5/edit#gid=1711326395)

to help you achieve this task.

üìã **Step 3:** Draw up a quick value proposition for each of the #1 ranking

actors and fill them out in the second tab of the ecosystem worksheet.

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 2: The Build-Up of Your Sustainability Plan

\## Welcome!

üìà This activity will help you understand your sustainability issues and

quantify your expenses and revenue sources.

Some of the topics discussed in this activity include:

üåª Identifying the level of urgency associated with sustainability issues (the

financial gap and runway).

üåª Applying a methodology to mitigate the financial gap and lengthen the

runway.

üåª The current, ideal, and contextualized revenue streams and their impact on

sustainability.

\## Let's get started!

\[üé¨ Watch the video here\](https://vimeo.com/737810344)

\## Explore some more...

Check this webinar from the World Bank Group about the \[financial

sustainability of business incubators and

accelerators\](https://olc.worldbank.org/content/cbin-webinar-series-financial-

sustainability-business-incubators-and-accelerators-0). The webinar covers

findings from the Global Accelerator Learning Initiative (GALI) report on the

funding profiles of 139 organizations that run accelerator programs.

\## Apply your knowledge!

üå± Using the \[Revenue Structure

Worksheet\](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1u8ZZAOaW6k14CLu1p5GOJh3vK5iWHrHY/edit?usp=share\_link&ouid=114780236206901783287&rtpof=true&sd=true),

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 2: Values Based Recruitment & Cultural Fit

\## Welcome!

What tools can you use to build a strong team culture?

Values based recruitment (VBR) is an approach to help attract and recruit

prospective employees whose personal values and behaviors align with those of

your organization. The best way to deliver VBR is through a Cultural Fit

Assessment.

As you watch the video, think about these questions:

üåª What are your team's core values that will attract good candidates?

üåª What are some sample interview questions that target your core values?

‚úçÔ∏è Take notes! It will help you complete the rest of the action.

\## Let's get started!

\[üé¨ Watch the video here\](https://vimeo.com/546366033)

\## Explore some more...

\* \[This article\](https://www.aaronwallis.co.uk/candidates/advice/sales-interview-advice/how-to-wow-at-value-based-interview/) gives a candidate's perspective on VBR.

\* This is an \[in-depth article\](https://www.aihr.com/blog/cultural-fit-assessment/) about Cultural Fit Assessments.

\* \[This article\](https://www.jobtestprep.com/culture-fit-test-prep#:~:text=Examples%20of%20Culture,culture%20interview%20questions%3A) lists some sample Cultural Fit interview questions.

\## Apply your knowledge!

It's time to create a Cultural Fit Assessment for your company ü•≥ Many samples

are available online, however, it is key that this document reflect your own

unique culture.

1\\. Now that your values are clear, write 3 behaviors that support each value

(must be an action sentence). For example:

Value: Social Awareness

Behavior 1: Analyze the internal and external social environment before taking

action.

2\\. Draft a culture fit questionnaire encompassing not more than 10 questions

(you can add more questions later).

Make sure you cover the 2 parts we discussed in the video:

\* Questions to bring personal values and behaviors to the surface.

\* Questions to benchmark and assess alignment with the core values of the organization.

üôå Great work! Save this document with your team's HR library. When the time

comes to recruit new team members, incorporate it into your interview process.

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 3: Highly Performing Team Dynamics & Development

\## Welcome!

Welcome to the final üéì Training Activity with Christine Francis! This activity

will help you understand the different stages of team culture and the role of

a strong team culture in achieving your goals üèÜ

üë´ A highly performing team is a group of people who work together harmoniously

to achieve an outcome much bigger than the number of people on the team if

they were to work individually. Direction is key to clarity, alignment is what

makes the team coherent, and commitment is what ensures success. The diversity

of the team members is important when it comes to thinking, skills sets,

expertise, and points of view. Diversity fuels innovation, but values and

cultural fit are key components of a successful enterprise.

As you watch the video, consider these questions:

üåª What are the four stages of the Tuckman Team Development Model?

üåª What are the communication and strength profiles of your team?

üåª What will it look like when your team starts "performing?"

\## Let's get started!

\[üé¨ Watch the video here\](https://vimeo.com/546439139)

\## Explore some more...

\* \[discprofile.com\](https://www.discprofile.com/) offers a workplace personality profiling service.

\## Apply your knowledge!

The 4 key components of highly effective teams when it comes to performance

and results are:

1\. Shared values and clear vision of KPI‚Äôs - **The What**!

2\. Who are our team members? What are their roles? How do their roles link to KPIs? - **The Who!**

3\. What is the plan to execute or achieve your vision? - **The How!**

4\. What is the timeline, the phases, etc.? - **The When**!

Briefly reflect on each of these points, then continue onto the Worksheet

linked below.

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 2: Collecting and Protecting Your Company Data

\## Welcome!

This activity covers processes related to gathering data for your accelerator

programs.

The EU has the most comprehensive and up-to-date regulations for data

compliance, so Anna's recommendations are based on these standards. However,

they can be adapted to any legal context with the help of a data compliance

expert. The topics include:

üåª Why data matters to accelerator programs.

üåª How to collect the right data for our needs.

üåª Where and how to collect it and how to process it, including the

responsibilities of the person on your team who looks after your data

collection and protection process.

üåª Further information about processing data, covering how to work with it in a

responsible and secure way.

üìù There's lots of valuable information here, so feel free to pause, take

notes, rewatch, or any other strategies that help you process.

\## Let's get started!

\[üé¨ Watch the video here\](https://vimeo.com/737823777)

\## Explore some more...

The actions stated in the EU's \[GDPR Checklist\](https://gdpr.eu/checklist/)

are the main things that a business needs to do in order to stay compliant.

Four important processes you need to have are:

\* The EU's \[Data Processing Agreement template\](https://gdpr.eu/data-processing-agreement/)

\* The EU‚Äôs \[template Privacy Policy\](https://gdpr.eu/privacy-notice/) for a website

\* Here is the EU‚Äôs \[advice on a Cookie Policy for a website\](https://gdpr.eu/cookies/), but they do not have a template. There are lots of companies today providing a service of being the pop-up on your website to deal with cookies permissions.

\* Here is a \[template of a GDPR register\](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1U71Qwtvt3gqXJUl3XvRkm9Wy28cSiRxo5f9V2farldo/edit?usp=sharing), which should be updated regularly in order to remain compliant with GDPR law. This template is only a guideline and should be checked with a local legal advisor before being implemented.

With these four things - a Data Protection Agreement, a Privacy Policy, a

Cookie Policy, and a GDPR Register - you are making good progress toward being

GDPR compliant. In all of your agreements, you should make sure that you add a

GDPR clause, but for this, you will need to seek local legal advice. Just ask

a local expert or data lawyer for the appropriate paragraphs to add.

\## Apply your knowledge!

Using \[this

spreadsheet\](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TCEMeP2iYcVpM9\_u221xlURHdWIudueY6dm9UsewtLY/edit?usp=sharing),

make a list of what kind of digital data you currently collect and what other

data you want to collect and why.

Share this list with other accelerators to see what data they think is

important to collect and why. Discuss together the challenges of collecting

data and how to overcome these challenges.

Finally, complete this \[example Risk & Asset

Register\](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1-fqQhL2Z8UGahiiQS\_gUUFfkkLhFCiCrYw71Z-Huj8E/edit?usp=sharing)

for your accelerator.

\## Title

üìñ Book: The Positive Dog: A Story About the Power of Positivity

\## Image

\* !\[\](/assets/attc1OW48aJfTw7eg-The\_Positive\_Dog\_by\_Jon\_Gordon)

\## Welcome!

We all have two dogs inside of us: one dog is positive, happy, optimistic, and

hopeful; the other dog is negative, mad, sad, pessimistic, and fearful. These

two dogs often fight inside us. The one who wins the fight is the one you feed

the most.

Being positive doesn't just make you better. It makes everyone around you

better.

This book teaches you how to:

‚≠ê Overcome negativity and challenges to become more positive

‚≠ê Use strategies and action plans to feed yourself and your team with

positivity

\## Let's get started!

\[üóíÔ∏è Read the book summary on

getAbstract.com\](https://www.getabstract.com/en/summary/the-positive-

dog/17814?u=Bloom)

\## Apply your knowledge!

Follow this 11-day action plan and build these activities into your daily

routine.

\## Title

üìñ Reading: The Seagull (Monologue)

\## Image

\* !\[\](/assets/attUARr9GX0dQQbBl-The\_Seagull\_by\_Anton\_Chekhov)

\## Welcome!

NINA: What do you mean you kissed the ground I walked on? I don‚Äôt deserve to

live. I‚Äôm so tired. If only I could rest ‚Äì I need rest! I‚Äôm the seagull ‚Äì but

I‚Äôm not really. I‚Äôm an actress. Yes. (She hears Arkadina and Trigorin

laughing.) So he‚Äôs here, too‚Ä¶well, it doesn‚Äôt matter. He never believed in

theatre, he always laughed at me for my dreams of being famous, and bit by bit

I stopped believing, too, and lost heart‚Ä¶there were all the other things to

worry about ‚Äì love, jealousy‚Ä¶and always the worry about the baby. I became

trivial and commonplace. My work lost all meaning. On stage I didn‚Äôt know what

to do with my hands or how to stand, I couldn‚Äôt control my voice‚Ä¶You can‚Äôt

know what it‚Äôs like when you‚Äôre up there feeling you‚Äôre acting so badly. The

seagull. No, that‚Äôs not me‚Ä¶you remember how you once shot that seagull? A man

happened to come along and see her, and having nothing much to do, destroyed

her. Idea for a short story‚Ä¶ No, that‚Äôs not it ‚Ä¶ what was I saying? Oh yes,

about acting‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not like that anymore. I‚Äôve become a real actress. I love

acting, when I‚Äôm on stage I feel drunk on the sheer joy of it, and I feel

beautiful. While I‚Äôve been back here I‚Äôve spent a lot of time walking and

thinking ‚Äì and every day I‚Äôve felt my spirit getting stronger. What I‚Äôve

realized, Kostya, is that, with us, whether we‚Äôre writers or actors, what

really counts is not dreaming about fame and glory‚Ä¶but stamina: knowing how to

keep going despite everything, and having faith in yourself ‚Äì I‚Äôve got faith

in myself now and that‚Äôs helped the pain, and when I think to myself, "You‚Äôre

on the stage!‚Äô then I‚Äôm not afraid of anything life can to do to me.

\](/recSD2bUa95tCaq0x.html)\[

\## Title

üìä Business Process: Dotmocracy

\## Image

\* !\[\](/assets/att0NcXUd8XF1YGuH-Dotmocracy)

\## Welcome!

Dotmocracy is a simple method for group prioritization or decision-making. It

is not an activity on its own, but a method to use in processes where

prioritization or decision-making is the aim. The method supports a group to

quickly see which options are most popular or relevant. The options or ideas

are written on post-its and stuck up on a wall for the whole group to see.

Each person votes for the options they think are the strongest, and that

information is used to inform a decision.

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 1: The Challenges Ahead

\## Welcome!

üå± In this activity, Giordano Dichter introduces you to the foundation of the

work to be done and the change needed to build your accelerator's

sustainability plan.

Some of the topics discussed in this activity include:

üåª The accelerator's business model challenges and limitations

üåª The need for diversification

üåª The target user and the strong suit

üåª The Ecosystem mapping

While you watch the video, think about the following questions:

ü§î Who are your target users? Who are the (potential) entrepreneurs you are

trying to help?

ü§î What is your strong suit with respect to your peers? What is your

differentiation factor (the one thing you are good at)?

ü§î What is your ecosystem looking like, and who could be interested in funding

your operations?

\## Let's get started!

\[document\](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Y9fue4PsXvplhJBpSoHUlzDDdiu6fW96/view?usp=sharing)

that identifies ways to catalyze finance for climate technology incubators and

accelerators in developing countries.

\## Apply your knowledge!

üë§ **Step 1:** Define your target users using the \[User Canvas

Then think about what makes you unique regarding the support you provide to

the users defined.

üåê **Step 2:** Map the ecosystem players interested in financing you in the

context where you operate, and fill them out in the first tab of the ecosystem

worksheet according to their priorities. Use the \[Ecosystem

to help you achieve this task.

actors and fill them out in the second tab of the ecosystem worksheet.

\## Title

\## Welcome!

Let's get started!

Organizational culture is a key factor of company sustainability. In today's

challenging and turbulent times, it is necessary to shift to a values-driven

culture. Rethinking how weave our collective values into our strategy and

business objectives will increase motivation, improve performance, and drive

results ‚úÖ

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 2: Values Based Recruitment & Cultural Fit

\## Welcome!

What tools can you use to build a strong team culture?

Values based recruitment (VBR) is an approach to help attract and recruit

prospective employees whose personal values and behaviors align with those of

your organization. The best way to deliver VBR is through a Cultural Fit

Assessment.

As you watch the video, think about these questions:

üåª What are your team's core values that will attract good candidates?

üåª What are some sample interview questions that target your core values?

‚úçÔ∏è Take notes! It will help you complete the rest of the action.

\## Let's get started!

\[üé¨ Watch the video here\](https://vimeo.com/546366033)

\## Explore some more...

\* \[This article\](https://www.aaronwallis.co.uk/candidates/advice/sales-interview-advice/how-to-wow-at-value-based-interview/) gives a candidate's perspective on VBR.

\* This is an \[in-depth article\](https://www.aihr.com/blog/cultural-fit-assessment/) about Cultural Fit Assessments.

\* \[This article\](https://www.jobtestprep.com/culture-fit-test-prep#:~:text=Examples%20of%20Culture,culture%20interview%20questions%3A) lists some sample Cultural Fit interview questions.

\## Apply your knowledge!

It's time to create a Cultural Fit Assessment for your company ü•≥ Many samples

are available online, however, it is key that this document reflect your own

unique culture.

1\\. Now that your values are clear, write 3 behaviors that support each value

(must be an action sentence). For example:

Value: Social Awareness

Behavior 1: Analyze the internal and external social environment before taking

action.

2\\. Draft a culture fit questionnaire encompassing not more than 10 questions

(you can add more questions later).

Make sure you cover the 2 parts we discussed in the video:

\* Questions to bring personal values and behaviors to the surface.

\* Questions to benchmark and assess alignment with the core values of the organization.

üôå Great work! Save this document with your team's HR library. When the time

comes to recruit new team members, incorporate it into your interview process.

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 3: Highly Performing Team Dynamics & Development

\## Welcome!

Welcome to the final üéì Training Activity with Christine Francis! This activity

will help you understand the different stages of team culture and the role of

a strong team culture in achieving your goals üèÜ

üë´ A highly performing team is a group of people who work together harmoniously

to achieve an outcome much bigger than the number of people on the team if

they were to work individually. Direction is key to clarity, alignment is what

makes the team coherent, and commitment is what ensures success. The diversity

of the team members is important when it comes to thinking, skills sets,

expertise, and points of view. Diversity fuels innovation, but values and

cultural fit are key components of a successful enterprise.

As you watch the video, consider these questions:

üåª What are the four stages of the Tuckman Team Development Model?

üåª What are the communication and strength profiles of your team?

üåª What will it look like when your team starts "performing?"

\## Let's get started!

\[üé¨ Watch the video here\](https://vimeo.com/546439139)

\## Explore some more...

\* \[discprofile.com\](https://www.discprofile.com/) offers a workplace personality profiling service.

\## Apply your knowledge!

The 4 key components of highly effective teams when it comes to performance

and results are:

1\. Shared values and clear vision of KPI‚Äôs - **The What**!

2\. Who are our team members? What are their roles? How do their roles link to KPIs? - **The Who!**

3\. What is the plan to execute or achieve your vision? - **The How!**

4\. What is the timeline, the phases, etc.? - **The When**!

Briefly reflect on each of these points, then continue onto the Worksheet

linked below.

\[Highly Performing Team Dynamics & Development

Worksheet\](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1L\_NZnATSx8DEtnW54XQAfq8eAgGXFRRkKq1BC5DAep8/edit)

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 2: Collecting and Protecting Your Company Data

\## Welcome!

This activity covers processes related to gathering data for your accelerator

programs.

The EU has the most comprehensive and up-to-date regulations for data

compliance, so Anna's recommendations are based on these standards. However,

they can be adapted to any legal context with the help of a data compliance

expert. The topics include:

üåª Why data matters to accelerator programs.

üåª How to collect the right data for our needs.

üåª Where and how to collect it and how to process it, including the

responsibilities of the person on your team who looks after your data

collection and protection process.

üåª Further information about processing data, covering how to work with it in a

responsible and secure way.

üìù There's lots of valuable information here, so feel free to pause, take

notes, rewatch, or any other strategies that help you process.

\## Let's get started!

\[üé¨ Watch the video here\](https://vimeo.com/737823777)

\## Explore some more...

The actions stated in the EU's \[GDPR Checklist\](https://gdpr.eu/checklist/)

are the main things that a business needs to do in order to stay compliant.

Four important processes you need to have are:

\* The EU's \[Data Processing Agreement template\](https://gdpr.eu/data-processing-agreement/)

\* The EU‚Äôs \[template Privacy Policy\](https://gdpr.eu/privacy-notice/) for a website

\* Here is the EU‚Äôs \[advice on a Cookie Policy for a website\](https://gdpr.eu/cookies/), but they do not have a template. There are lots of companies today providing a service of being the pop-up on your website to deal with cookies permissions.

\* Here is a \[template of a GDPR register\](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1U71Qwtvt3gqXJUl3XvRkm9Wy28cSiRxo5f9V2farldo/edit?usp=sharing), which should be updated regularly in order to remain compliant with GDPR law. This template is only a guideline and should be checked with a local legal advisor before being implemented.

With these four things - a Data Protection Agreement, a Privacy Policy, a

Cookie Policy, and a GDPR Register - you are making good progress toward being

GDPR compliant. In all of your agreements, you should make sure that you add a

GDPR clause, but for this, you will need to seek local legal advice. Just ask

a local expert or data lawyer for the appropriate paragraphs to add.

\## Apply your knowledge!

Using \[this

spreadsheet\](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1TCEMeP2iYcVpM9\_u221xlURHdWIudueY6dm9UsewtLY/edit?usp=sharing),

make a list of what kind of digital data you currently collect and what other

data you want to collect and why.

Share this list with other accelerators to see what data they think is

important to collect and why. Discuss together the challenges of collecting

data and how to overcome these challenges.

Finally, complete this \[example Risk & Asset

Register\](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1-fqQhL2Z8UGahiiQS\_gUUFfkkLhFCiCrYw71Z-Huj8E/edit?usp=sharing)

for your accelerator.

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 3: Building a Responsible and Sustainable Program

\## Welcome!

This final video will help you run your program responsibly and sustainably -

legal policies, financial processes, and, since many people think that these

are the ‚Äònon-exciting parts‚Äô of accelerators, how to set the right attitude

when working in these areas.

Anna will guide you through the following topics:

üåª The legal agreements and policies that you should consider having and how to

make them applicable to your team.

üåª Meetings and ways of working that will help you keep on top of your

financials.

üåª Looking at the bold idea of publicizing all your efforts and how this can

positively impact your program.

\## Let's get started!

\[üé¨ Watch the video here\](https://vimeo.com/737824322)

\## Explore some more...

Here are some recommended resources from Anna:

\* \[How to outsource some of your HR obligations\](https://www.gan.co/blog/hiring-remote-employees-hard/) to focus your energy on what you do well.

\* Workable has \[this resource\](https://resources.workable.com/employee-handbook-policies) to help create an employee handbook and accompanying policies.

\* Here is \[a nice article about great examples of Employee Handbooks\](https://blog.airmason.com/the-10-best-employee-handbook-examples/).

\## Apply your knowledge!

This video has a lot of small tips in it, with lots of things to research and

check. Security and financial processes can seem urgent, but you only have

limited time to dedicate to these details. So, create a checklist and

prioritize the list.

üìù Here is \[a template

checklist\](https://docs.google.com/document/d/135mxucH7FmGHoAjl0RV1dqejAVynMz58Q7XJoAu7Mv0/edit?usp=sharing)

of things you should do to attain good compliance. Use this checklist to see

what you have already completed, have not finalized, or have not even thought

about! Create a list of your top 3 priorities to complete this month. You can

discuss with your colleagues what they think are the high-priority items.

If a document is referred to here, but a template has not been provided,

either this is because you should seek local advice. Health and safety laws,

employment laws, and IT security laws differ greatly from region to region.

\## Title

üéì Training Activity 1: Planning for Success

\## Welcome!

üå± Welcome to the first Activity of this module. In this activity,

communication expert Anna Thomlinson discusses the following topics:

üåª How communications convey stories.

üåª Why founders and startups should be Heroes at the center of your

communications messages.

üåª How to make your story reach a broad audience.

üåª How a Communications Plan can improve your messaging and schedule workloads.

‚òÄÔ∏è By the end of this Activity, you will start working on your Communication

plan targets.

template.

registering.

üöÄ Step 3:

your communications plan.

\## Title

üìñ Book: The Positive Dog: A Story About the Power of Positivity

\## Image

\* !\[\](/assets/attc1OW48aJfTw7eg-The\_Positive\_Dog\_by\_Jon\_Gordon)

\## Welcome!

We all have two dogs inside of us: one dog is positive, happy, optimistic, and

hopeful; the other dog is negative, mad, sad, pessimistic, and fearful. These

two dogs often fight inside us. The one who wins the fight is the one you feed

the most.

Being positive doesn't just make you better. It makes everyone around you

better.

This book teaches you how to:

‚≠ê Overcome negativity and challenges to become more positive

‚≠ê Use strategies and action plans to feed yourself and your team with

positivity

\## Let's get started!

dog/17814?u=Bloom)

\## Apply your knowledge!

Follow this 11-day action plan and build these activities into your daily

routine.

‚ú® Day 1: Take a thank-you walk

‚ú® Day 2: A day of gratitude

‚ú® Day 3: More smiles and laughter

‚ú® Day 4: Celebrate your success of the day

‚ú® Day 5: Spend time with positive people

‚ú® Day 6: Share the gift of kindness

‚ú® Day 7: Smell the roses

‚ú® Day 8: Envision your future

‚ú® Day 9: Make a gratitude visit

‚ú® Day 10: Lose yourself in the moment

‚ú® Day 11: Be a positivity coach

\## Title

üìñ Reading: The Seagull (Monologue)

\## Image

\* !\[\](/assets/attUARr9GX0dQQbBl-The\_Seagull\_by\_Anton\_Chekhov)

\## Welcome!

NINA: What do you mean you kissed the ground I walked on? I don‚Äôt deserve to

live. I‚Äôm so tired. If only I could rest ‚Äì I need rest! I‚Äôm the seagull ‚Äì but

I‚Äôm not really. I‚Äôm an actress. Yes. (She hears Arkadina and Trigorin

laughing.) So he‚Äôs here, too‚Ä¶well, it doesn‚Äôt matter. He never believed in

theatre, he always laughed at me for my dreams of being famous, and bit by bit

I stopped believing, too, and lost heart‚Ä¶there were all the other things to

worry about ‚Äì love, jealousy‚Ä¶and always the worry about the baby. I became

trivial and commonplace. My work lost all meaning. On stage I didn‚Äôt know what

to do with my hands or how to stand, I couldn‚Äôt control my voice‚Ä¶You can‚Äôt

know what it‚Äôs like when you‚Äôre up there feeling you‚Äôre acting so badly. The

seagull. No, that‚Äôs not me‚Ä¶you remember how you once shot that seagull? A man

happened to come along and see her, and having nothing much to do, destroyed

her. Idea for a short story‚Ä¶ No, that‚Äôs not it ‚Ä¶ what was I saying? Oh yes,

about acting‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not like that anymore. I‚Äôve become a real actress. I love

acting, when I‚Äôm on stage I feel drunk on the sheer joy of it, and I feel

beautiful. While I‚Äôve been back here I‚Äôve spent a lot of time walking and

thinking ‚Äì and every day I‚Äôve felt my spirit getting stronger. What I‚Äôve

realized, Kostya, is that, with us, whether we‚Äôre writers or actors, what

really counts is not dreaming about fame and glory‚Ä¶but stamina: knowing how to

keep going despite everything, and having faith in yourself ‚Äì I‚Äôve got faith

in myself now and that‚Äôs helped the pain, and when I think to myself, "You‚Äôre

on the stage!‚Äô then I‚Äôm not afraid of anything life can to do to me.

\](/recSD2bUa95tCaq0x.html)\[

A simple exercise that complements exploratory, discursive, and creative

workshops with insights and opinions from outside. Use this exercise when

brainstorming ideas, developing a new product or service or creating a

strategy or plan that will include others. Participants phone a co-worker and

surprised at how simple it was to solicit this input and how valuable it is to

the process.

\## Title

üìä Business Process: Dotmocracy

\## Image

\* !\[\](/assets/att0NcXUd8XF1YGuH-Dotmocracy)

\## Welcome!

Dotmocracy is a simple method for group prioritization or decision-making. It

is not an activity on its own, but a method to use in processes where

prioritization or decision-making is the aim. The method supports a group to

quickly see which options are most popular or relevant. The options or ideas

are written on post-its and stuck up on a wall for the whole group to see.

Each person votes for the options they think are the strongest, and that

information is used to inform a decision.

\](/recUoQ4cmgi50khD7.html)
